note: Much of his most recent work has been devoted to Cicero’s ethical and political thought.
title: Malcolm Schofield is Emeritus Professor of Ancient Philosophy at the University of Cambridge. He has taught ancient Greek and Roman philosophy in Cambridge for over forty years, after earlier positions at Cornell and Balliol College, Oxford. He is the co-author (with G.S
Raven) of the second edition of The Presocratic Philosophers
and many other publications

note: Euripides: Bacchae (1996), Dionysos (2006), Money and the Early Greek Mind
title: Richard Seaford is Emeritus Professor of Greek at the University of Exeter. His books include Euripides: Cyclops (1984) Reciprocity and Ritual
In 2009 he was Honorary President of the Classical Association (UK). He is currently preparing a monograph comparing early Greek with early Indian thought

note: He produced the first major anthology of Galen’s works in English translation (Galen: Selected Works, 1997) and is editor of Galen: Psychological Writings (2013), the first volume of a major new series. He has taught at King’s and Birkbeck Colleges, London; was from 2009 to 2014 Research Associate at Newcastle University; and currently holds a
title: David Sedley taught 1975–2014 at the University of Cambridge, where he was Laurence Professor of Ancient Philosophy from 2000, and remains a Fellow of Christ’s College. He has been editor of Classical Quarterly (1986–92) and Oxford Studies in Ancient Philosophy
His books include: (with A.A. Long) The Hellenistic Philosophers
Lucretius and the Transformation of Greek Wisdom (1998); Plato’s Cratylus
The Midwife of Platonism: Text and Subtext in Plato’s Theaetetus (2004); and Creationism and its Critics in Antiquity

based on his 2004 Sather Lectures. P.N. Singer’s research centres on psychological theory, ethics, and medical writing in the Graeco-Roman world. While focusing especially on Galen, he has also published on the Hippocratic corpus, on Hellenistic and post-Hellenistic popular ethicists and on philosophical and medical authority and literary genre in the second century CE
